items.description: River Severn at Sandhurst and Maisemore
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Gloucester river gauge as a result of high spring tides coinciding with high river levels.  Flooding is possible on high tides at Gloucester over the next few days.  We expect flooding to affect Coal Wharf and Riverside, Maisemore, low lying areas on Base Lane, Sandhurst. Sandhurst Lane will be just passable. The A417 at Maisemore may be closed due to flooding. Predicted Peaks:- Sandhurst 3.4m to 3.6m 03/03/22 at 22:30 and 3.6m to 3.8m on 04/03/22 at 10:30, Gloucester 3.5m to 3.7m 03/03/22 at 22:15 and 3.6m to 3.8m 04/03/22 at 10:30.   
We expect river levels to remain high over the next 4 days.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 14:00 on 04/03/22, or as the situation changes.

Sea spray overtopping is forecast along the coast as a result of high tides. First forecast high water is 19:45 on 03/03/22 with a level of 6.26 mAOD and a Force 5 Westerly wind. Second forecast high water is 08:00 on 4/03/22 with a level of 6.47 mAOD and a Force 4 North West wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkley Point, mAOD is height above average sea level for more detail refer to local tide tables. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide. Areas most at risk are the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads. This message will be updated Friday, 04/03/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.78mAOD at 16:15 on 04/03/22 and 4.71mAOD at 04:30 on 05/03/22.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are peaking today. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 148 cubic metres per second and is falling slowly. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 10:00 on 05/03/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels continue to rise slowly at the Cae Howel river gauge following recent persistent rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding of roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Predicted peaks:- Llanymynech peaked at 2.83m overnight; Cae Howel 3.3 to 3.5m today, Friday 04/03/22. No further rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high until Saturday, 05/03/22. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated by 9am on Saturday 05/03/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels continue to rise slowly at the Lugwardine river gauge following recent persistent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop. No further significant rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high until Sunday, 06/03/22. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated by 9am on Saturday 05/03/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Shropshire, Staffordshire, Telford and Wrekin, Wrexham

items.message: River levels remain high and continue to rise slowly at the Tern - Walcot river gauge following recent persistent rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington. We expect river levels to remain high over the weekend. No further rainfall is forecast. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated by 9am on Saturday 05/03/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Teme, River Onny, River Corve

items.message: River levels continue to rise slowly at the Leintwardine river gauge following recent persistent rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding of roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the River Teme, River Onny and River Corve and their tributaries. Locations that may be affected include Bishops Castle, Church Stretton, Knighton and Ludlow. Predicted peaks:- Onibury peaked at 1.76m last night, Leintwardine 1 to 1.2m today, Friday 04/03/22. No further rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high until Friday afternoon, 04/03/22. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated by 9am on Saturday 05/03/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected this afternoon, 04/03/2022 and into tomorrow 05/03/2022. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high over the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated this evening, 04/03/2022, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels have risen on the River Thame following rainfall over the last few days. Flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue especially close to the river around Dorchester-on-Thames, Thame and Stadhampton. Further rainfall is forecast today (Friday 4th March) with further rain tomorrow. We expect river levels to continue to rise very slowly before stabilising over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this afternoon, or as the situation changes.

River levels are continuing to fall at the Dernford river gauge, but levels remain high on the River Cam downstream. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, Friday 04/03/2022. We expect flooding to affect River Cam from Stapleford to Waterbeach. Further rainfall is forecast today, Friday 04/03/22. We expect river levels to remain high today, Friday 04/03/2022. River levels may rise again in response to further rainfall. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded, and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. We are closely monitoring the situation. This message will be updated this afternoon, 04/03/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels have gradually risen overnight at the Ashford river gauge as a result of rainfall. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Ashford and Bakewell areas. Further rainfall is forecast over the next six hours. We expect river levels to continue to rise gradually this morning, Friday 04/03/22 before beginning to fall away later today.  We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated this afternoon, 04/03/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Severn estuary from Gloucester to Sharpness
items.message: High tides combined with high fluvial river levels will be at their highest between 22:00 and 23:00 this Thursday evening, 03/03/22 and 10:15 and 11:15 Friday morning, 04/03/22. Flooding to roads and farmland is expected at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Severn Estuary from Sandhurst to Chepstow and Sharpness. Locations affected; low lying land at Lower Rea and Elmore Lane West may be flooded. High tides may also affect watercourses draining into the Severn Estuary. Predicted peaks:- Sandhurst 3.4m to 3.6m 03/03/22 at 22:30 and 3.6m to 3.8m on 04/03/22 at 10:30, Gloucester 3.5m to 3.7m 03/03/22 at 22:15 and 3.6m to 3.8m 04/03/22 at 10:30. Flooding is not expected at other tidal gauge locations. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 14:00 on 04/03/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message: This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 08:30 AM on Friday 04/03/2022. Areas most at risk include the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton. The detailed tidal information for those who use it is for a peak level at Avonmouth of 7.46 mAODN at 08:30 AM on 04/03/2022, which is 0.12 m above tide tables, with north-westerly force 3 winds. (mAODN is height above average sea level - for more info refer to local tide tables.) There has been light rainfall throughout Thursday morning. The Thursday evening tide at 08:15 PM on 03/03/2022 is not expected to reach the flood alert level. We are expecting a series of high spring tides over the next two mornings and as a result this alert will remain in force until at least Saturday afternoon. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences. This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 04/03/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message: River levels are forecast to rise at the Torksey river gauge as a result of high spring tides coinciding with high river levels. Flooding is possible on high tides at 23:00 on 04/03/22 and 11:00 on 05/03/22 at Torksey. Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road. We expect river levels to peak on the high tide at 23:30 on 05/03/22 at Torksey. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 20:00 on 04/03/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Cosford river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding is imminent.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River from Crackley Bank to Bridgnorth. Other locations that may be affected include Ryton and Burcote.   
No further rainfall is forecast.  We expect river levels to remain high until Sunday, 06/03/22. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.   
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated  by 9am on 05/03/22, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are forecast to rise on the River Thames as a result of high tides. The next high tide is expected at Trowlock Island this afternoon the 4th March at 4:30 pm and is forecast to reach approximately 5.05-5.20 metres. The river is expected to overtop banks and flood low lying land. The following high tide is expected at 5:00 am tomorrow and is forecast to reach approximately 5.05-5.20 metres. The river is expected to overtop banks and flood low lying land.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. The Thames Barrier is not currently forecast to close for the high tides this afternoon and tomorrow morning. 
This message will be updated this evening, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Rhee in Central Bedfordshire, Hertfordshire and Cambridgeshire
items.message: River levels are falling at the Wimpole river gauge, but levels remain high downstream following recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, Friday 04/03/2022. We expect flooding to affect River Rhee from Guilden Morden to Haslingfield. Further rainfall is forecast today, Friday 04/03/22. We expect river levels to remain high throughout today, Friday 04/03/22. River levels may rise again in response to further rainfall. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated this afternoon, 04/03/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message: River levels continue to rise at the Sutton Gault river gauge following recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, Friday 04/03/2022. We expect flooding to affect the Hundred Foot Washes, also known as the Ouse Washes. Further rainfall is forecast today, Friday 04/03/22. We expect river levels to remain high throughout Friday, 04/03/22. This information is correct as of 07:30 on Friday 04 March. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 16 centimetres of water on the road. There are currently no issues on the Welney or Earith causeways. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 16:00 this afternoon, 04/03/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels continue to rise at the Sutton Gault river gauge following recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, Friday 04/03/22. We expect flooding to affect The Causeway at Sutton Gault. Further rainfall is forecast today, Friday 04/03/22. We expect river levels to remain high throughout Friday, 04/03/2022. This information is correct as of 07:30 on Friday 04 March. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 16 centimetres of water on the road. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. The Environment Agency are liaising with Cambridgeshire Highways, who will decide whether to close the road. This alert applies to SUTTON GAULT CAUSEWAY ONLY. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 16:00 this afternoon, 04/03/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels on the Chertsey Bourne are falling slowly, but remain high and out of banks in some locations in Chertsey. Flooding of some low lying land and roads in Chertsey is expected to continue today 04/03/22. 
We expect river levels to remain high on the Chertsey Bourne today and tomorrow 05/03/22. River levels could rise again in response to further rainfall forecast for today and tomorrow. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this afternoon, 04/03/22, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are beginning to fall slowly but remain high and out of banks in some locations on the Lower River Loddon. Flooding of low lying land and roads is therefore expected to continue today 04/03/22, especially in and around Sindlesham Mill, Winnersh Triangle and Whistley Green.   
We expect river levels to remain high on the Lower River Loddon today and tomorrow 05/03/22. River levels could rise again in response to further rainfall forecast for today and tomorrow.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this afternoon 04/03/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames from Hampton and Thames Ditton to Teddington

floodArea.county: Greater London, Kingston upon Thames, Richmond upon Thames, Surrey

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are forecast to rise on the River Thames as a result of high tides. The next high tide is expected at Kingston this afternoon the 4th March at 4:30 pm and is forecast to reach approximately 5-5.15 metres. The river could overtop banks and flood low lying land, roads and footpaths in some locations. The following high tide is expected at 5:00 am tomorrow and is forecast to reach approximately 5-5.15 metres. The river could overtop banks and flood low lying land, roads and footpaths in some locations.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. The Thames Barrier is not currently forecast to close for the high tides this afternoon and tomorrow morning. 
This message will be updated this evening, or as the situation changes.

River levels have continued to fall throughout today 03/03/22 on the Upper River Wey and the river is now back within its banks. There may still be standing water in the floodplain in some low lying areas adjacent to the river. River levels could rise again in response to forecast rainfall overnight and tomorrow. We will continue to monitor the weather forecast and reissue this alert if necessary, but further flooding is not currently expected.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river level information.

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. No property flooding is expected and minimal rainfall is forecast over the next few days.
River levels are now falling steadily at the Bradford on Avon and Semington gauges.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  No further rainfall is forecast.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.

items.description: River Pang from East Ilsley to Pangbourne and Sulham Brook
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  Light rainfall is forecast overnight with a risk of light showers tomorrow. However, we do not expect this to cause a flood risk along the River Pang. We continue to monitor the situation. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: The risk of flooding from the River Clyst has now reduced, and river levels are falling below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

River levels have continued to fall throughout today 03/03/22 on the Hoe Stream and the river is now back within its banks. There may still be standing water in the floodplain in some low lying areas adjacent to the river, especially in the Woking area. River levels could rise again in response to forecast rainfall overnight and tomorrow. We will continue to monitor the weather forecast and reissue this alert if necessary, but further flooding is not currently expected.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river level information.

items.description: River Blackwater and The Cove Brook
items.message:
River levels have continued to fall throughout today 03/03/22 on the River Blackwater and Cove Brook and the river is now back within its banks. There may still be standing water in the floodplain in some low lying areas adjacent to the river, especially in the Swallowfield area. River levels could rise again in response to forecast rainfall overnight and tomorrow. We will continue to monitor the weather forecast and reissue this alert if necessary, but further flooding is not currently expected.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river level information.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Windle Brook, Hale Bourne, Mill Bourne, Addlestone Bourne

items.message:
River levels on the Addlestone Bourne remain high but are falling slowly and the river is flowing within its banks. There may be standing water in the floodplain in some low lying areas adjacent to the river. River levels could rise again in response to forecast rainfall today 04/03/22 and tomorrow. We will continue to monitor the weather forecast and reissue this alert if necessary, but further flooding isnt currently expected.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river level information.

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames

items.message: The high tide at Richmond has now passed, and fluvial levels on the River Crane have now fallen below levels of concern.  No further flooding to gardens and low lying land is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.
